course_title: Variable Topics in Women, Gender & Sexuality Studies: Jewish Women in Modern World

class_notes:
(Same as JS 273 2 and REL 270 7)
(Gender as a category of analysis grew out of the women's movement and the turn to social history in the 1970s, and its dual roots in political activism and academic discourse have given it tremendous power to expand and transform our understandings of fundamental aspects of Jewish religious, historical, and cultural development.  In this course, we'll explore the experience of Jewish women as they accommodated to the socioeconomic and ideological challenges of modernity in Europe and the United States, and how ideas about gender played a role in the construction of Jewish identities in the modern period.  Using a gendered lens, we'll ask how gender and sexuality 
fundamentally shaped modern Jewish historical experience, identity, ideology, and imagination from the 17th  century forward.  To do so, we will not simply "add women and stir," to borrow a phrase from feminist historians; rather, we will query how gender - the culturally and hierarchically constructed differences between the sexes based on perceived differences - has influenced women's lives and actions.)
